questions.question: What are the three Scrum artifacts and their primary purposes?
options: Product Backlog (requirements), Sprint Backlog (tasks), Increment (deliverable)
Product Backlog (transparency of work), Sprint Backlog (transparency of Sprint), Increment (transparency of progress)
Product Vision (direction), Sprint Plan (execution), Product Release (delivery)
Requirements Document (scope), Work Breakdown (tasks), Deliverable (output)
questions.explanation: The three Scrum artifacts are Product Backlog (transparency of work to be done), Sprint Backlog (transparency of work planned for the Sprint), and Increment (transparency of work completed and progress toward Product Goal).

questions.question: What is the Product Owner's primary accountability regarding Scrum artifacts?
options: Creating all three artifacts and maintaining their quality
Managing the Product Backlog to maximize product value
Ensuring the Sprint Backlog aligns with stakeholder expectations
Approving each Increment before it can be released
questions.explanation: The Product Owner is accountable for managing the Product Backlog to maximize the value of the product. While they collaborate on other artifacts, the Product Backlog is their primary artifact responsibility.

questions.question: A Product Owner notices that Sprint Backlogs consistently include work that wasn't in the original Sprint Planning. The Development Team says they're 'discovering necessary tasks.' What should the Product Owner investigate?
options: Whether the Development Team is properly skilled for the work
Whether Product Backlog items are sufficiently refined before Sprint Planning
Whether the Sprint length needs to be increased
Whether the Scrum Master is providing adequate guidance
questions.explanation: Consistently discovering unplanned work suggests Product Backlog items aren't sufficiently refined. The Product Owner should investigate whether items are properly understood and detailed before Sprint Planning to reduce surprises.

questions.question: A Product Owner wants to release functionality mid-Sprint that the Development Team says is 'working but not done.' The feature passes user acceptance testing but doesn't meet some Definition of Done criteria. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Release the functionality since it meets user needs
Wait until the work meets the full Definition of Done
Create a separate Definition of Done for urgent releases
Release with documented technical debt to address later
questions.explanation: The Definition of Done cannot be compromised. It ensures quality and sustainable development. The Product Owner should wait until work truly meets the Definition of Done before releasing, even if it delays the release.

questions.question: A Product Owner's stakeholders complain that they can't understand product progress from Sprint Reviews. They want detailed documentation of what was accomplished. How should the Product Owner respond?
options: Create comprehensive documentation after each Sprint
Improve the Sprint Review to better demonstrate the working Increment
Ask the Development Team to provide detailed progress reports
Schedule separate stakeholder briefings with documentation
questions.explanation: The Increment itself should provide transparency about progress. The Product Owner should improve Sprint Reviews to better demonstrate working functionality rather than relying on documentation, which provides less valuable transparency.

questions.question: A Product Owner is refining Product Backlog items for an upcoming Sprint. Which characteristics should they ensure items have? (Choose all that apply)
options: Items are valuable to users or stakeholders
Items include detailed technical implementation plans
Items are small enough to be completed within a Sprint
Items are testable and have clear acceptance criteria
questions.explanation: Good Product Backlog items should be valuable, appropriately sized for Sprint completion, and testable with clear acceptance criteria. Technical implementation details should emerge through collaboration, not be specified upfront.

questions.question: A Product Owner discovers that the team's Definition of Done doesn't include performance testing, but customers are complaining about slow response times. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Add performance requirements to individual Product Backlog items
Work with the team to improve the Definition of Done to include performance standards
Accept the current situation since the Definition of Done is set
Create separate performance testing Sprints
questions.explanation: The Definition of Done should evolve to ensure quality that meets user needs. The Product Owner should work with the team to improve the Definition of Done to include performance standards, preventing future quality issues.

questions.question: During Sprint Planning, the Development Team says several 'Ready' Product Backlog items actually need significant clarification. This has happened multiple times. What should the Product Owner address?
options: The Definition of Ready needs improvement and consistent application
Sprint Planning should be longer to accommodate discovery
The Development Team needs better analysis skills
Product Backlog items should include more detailed specifications
questions.explanation: Recurring issues with 'Ready' items indicate the Definition of Ready needs improvement. The Product Owner should work with the team to clarify and consistently apply readiness criteria to prevent Sprint Planning disruptions.

questions.question: A Product Owner notices that Increments are created throughout the Sprint, but stakeholders only see progress during Sprint Reviews. How can the Product Owner improve transparency?
options: Require stakeholders to attend daily check-ins
Create detailed progress reports between Sprint Reviews
Make Increments visible to stakeholders as they're completed
Wait until Sprint Reviews to show any progress
questions.explanation: Transparency is improved by making Increments visible as they're completed, not just at Sprint Reviews. This provides stakeholders with real-time visibility into progress and enables faster feedback.

questions.question: A Product Owner faces pressure to release an Increment with known security vulnerabilities because 'customers are waiting.' The vulnerabilities don't meet the Definition of Done, but marketing says the delay will cost sales. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Release with vulnerabilities and fix them in the next release
Negotiate a partial release of features that meet the Definition of Done
Maintain the Definition of Done and work with the team to address security issues
Create a temporary exception to the Definition of Done for this release
questions.explanation: The Definition of Done ensures quality and cannot be compromised, especially for security issues. The Product Owner should maintain standards and work with the team to address issues, protecting long-term value over short-term gains.

questions.question: Stakeholders ask the Product Owner for a traditional project plan with delivery dates for all Product Backlog items. How should the Product Owner provide transparency while managing expectations?
options: Create fixed delivery dates for all Product Backlog items
Provide a prioritized view of the Product Backlog with expected sequencing but explain the empirical nature of delivery
Refuse to provide any timeline information
Ask the Development Team to commit to specific delivery dates
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should provide transparency about priorities and likely sequencing while educating stakeholders about empirical development. Fixed dates create false certainty that contradicts Scrum's empirical approach.

questions.question: A Development Team tells the Product Owner they cannot meet the Definition of Done due to missing automated testing infrastructure. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Lower the Definition of Done to match current capabilities
Add infrastructure work to the Product Backlog and prioritize it appropriately
Accept partially done work and plan to add testing later
Outsource the infrastructure work to avoid impacting feature delivery
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should add necessary infrastructure work to the Product Backlog and prioritize it appropriately. The Definition of Done should not be compromised, and infrastructure is essential for sustainable delivery.

questions.question: A Product Owner consistently brings large, unrefined items to Sprint Planning, causing long planning sessions and incomplete Sprint Backlogs. The team is frustrated. What is the core issue the Product Owner must address?
options: The Sprint Planning timebox is too short for complex items
The Development Team lacks estimation skills for large items
Product Backlog refinement is not happening effectively between Sprints
The Product Owner needs to provide more detailed specifications
questions.explanation: The core issue is ineffective Product Backlog refinement. The Product Owner should ensure items are properly refined before Sprint Planning, breaking down large items and clarifying requirements through ongoing refinement activities.

questions.question: A Product Owner wants to measure team productivity by counting completed Product Backlog items per Sprint. What are the problems with this approach?
options: Different items have different complexity and value
It focuses on output rather than outcomes and value delivery
It may encourage gaming the system by splitting or combining items artificially
All of the above
questions.explanation: All these issues apply. Counting items ignores complexity differences, focuses on output over value, and may encourage gaming. Product Owners should focus on value delivery and customer outcomes rather than item counts.

questions.question: A Product Owner discovers that the Development Team has been adding technical debt items to Sprint Backlogs without discussion. What should the Product Owner do to improve transparency and decision-making?
options: Forbid the team from working on technical debt
Add technical debt items to the Product Backlog for proper prioritization
Allow the team to continue managing technical debt independently
Create separate technical debt Sprints
questions.explanation: Technical debt items should be visible in the Product Backlog and prioritized by the Product Owner. This ensures transparency and allows informed decisions about balancing technical work with new features.

questions.question: A Product Owner is preparing for a Sprint Review where they'll demonstrate the Increment. Which statements about the Increment are true? (Choose all that apply)
options: It must be in usable condition even if the Product Owner chooses not to release it
It includes all work completed in the current Sprint plus all previous Increments
It can only be demonstrated at the end of the Sprint
It must meet the Definition of Done to be considered complete
questions.explanation: The Increment must be usable, includes all previous work, and must meet the Definition of Done. However, Increments can be created and potentially demonstrated multiple times during a Sprint, not just at the end.

questions.question: The organization's Definition of Done includes 'deployed to production,' but there's a separate business approval process before features can be released to customers. How should the Product Owner handle this conflict?
options: Remove deployment from the Definition of Done
Include business approval in the Definition of Done
Deploy to production but keep features disabled until approved
Work with the organization to align the Definition of Done with actual release capability
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should work to align the Definition of Done with actual release capability. The Definition should represent work that could realistically be released, considering all organizational constraints.

questions.question: Senior management pressures a Product Owner to release an Increment with known quality issues, saying 'we can fix problems later.' The issues violate the Definition of Done. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Release the Increment to maintain management support
Refuse to release and explain the long-term consequences of compromising quality
Release but clearly document all known issues and risks
Temporarily lower the Definition of Done for this release
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should refuse to compromise the Definition of Done and explain the long-term consequences. Quality debt compounds over time and undermines future value delivery. Maintaining standards protects long-term product success.

questions.question: A Product Owner is managing a complex product with multiple stakeholder groups. They're considering creating separate Product Backlogs for each group to manage demands. What is the primary risk of this approach?
options: It increases the Product Owner's workload significantly
It fragments the product vision and makes value optimization difficult
It violates Scrum rules about having one Product Backlog
It reduces stakeholder transparency into each other's requirements
questions.explanation: The primary risk is fragmenting the product vision and making it difficult to optimize overall value. The Product Owner needs a single view of all work to make effective trade-off decisions that maximize value for the entire product.

questions.question: A Product Owner has been creating detailed specifications, mockups, and test cases for Product Backlog items before refinement. The Development Team says this reduces their engagement and creativity. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Continue with detailed specifications to ensure quality and reduce ambiguity
Create lighter initial specifications and encourage collaborative refinement
Eliminate all upfront specifications and rely entirely on conversation
Ask the Development Team to create their own detailed specifications
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should balance initial clarity with collaborative engagement. Over-specification reduces team creativity and buy-in, while under-specification creates confusion. Collaborative refinement often produces better solutions.
